name: Kepler-334
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-334 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-334 is a star with 1.052 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.07 times its radius. It is located 1408.54 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-334 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-334 b

Kepler-334 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.47 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-334.

The mass of Kepler-334 b is 1.27 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-334 b is 1.12 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-334 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-334 c

Kepler-334 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 12.76 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-334.

The mass of Kepler-334 c is 2.29 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-334 c is 1.43 that of Earth. At 2.29 Earth masses, Kepler-334 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-334 d

Kepler-334 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.17 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 25.10 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-334.

The mass of Kepler-334 d is 2.20 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-334 d is 1.41 that of Earth. At 2.20 Earth masses, Kepler-334 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-334, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
